1.subquestion: Identify every possible combination of three distinct nonzero coordinates within the grid above. There are __ combinations total since order doesn't matter & no repetitions allowed.

subanswer.text:
Every point corresponds uniquely to its row and column index, so pick any vertical or horizontal pair along which you want your trio to align. Then only need fill in third coordinate at top edge OR bottom edge OR left side OR right hand corner.
Choices include: Row pairs [row_col], Row&TopEdge Pairs [(r), (r+c)], LeftPiece[(l),(m*k)] RightCorner [(N-(n*(m-1))), ((M-1)*K+(p))] where r, c, n, p integers such that Rows sum up N <= M.
Examples:(1,4)(2,4)(3,4) (2,2)(2,4)(3,4) (2,2)(4,2)(5,2) ......etc... Total choices count to 56 Combinations because choosing permutation wouldn’t change output.(Note rows have been labeled as m and columns k.) Answer choice counts here would still equal .__ Choice Counts = Rows sums<=columns==sum!=rows=>no solution Sum == cols =>solution exists=(number solutions)=total possibilities/(choices per possibility)= total possibilties=/max(cols)-min(rows)+1*\(\prod\)from \(i=min\_rows \)to \(\leq max_{rows}\)of (\(\prod\)overall coords not yet filled-\(choose\,#\,nonzeros \,per \,filled\;coordinate)\,+\)column fills available +\(top,\;bottom,\;side,\;corner \;fills\). Therefore ,choice quantities must divide equally into total possibilites without remainder ; otherwise chance isn't uniform! Excluding symmetries yields just those sets wthout mirror image about diagonal axis—including diagonally opposite corners but excluding middle vertex itself due symmetry cutting through center square twice (one reflection flips vertically while another reverses horizontality ). So calculate using remaining options after removing duplicates caused by reflections off axes plus central overlap case separately beforehand… This means our final denominator becomes something like " Total Possibilities/\([({MaxColumn}-MinimumRow )}+{(ProductOfAllCoordinatePossibleValues)-"choose", "(NumberNonZero","PerFilledCoord")}" where product term accounts how far away current position could end either northward eastward southwestwards west

solution based on your initial problem statement related to selecting random points on a grid such as a tic-tac-toe board. Here’s how to proceed methodically:

Step 1: Define Grid Configuration  
We start with identifying our playing field. Typically, one might consider a standard 3x3 square grid similar to what is used in games like Tic-Tac-Toe. However, without specifying dimensions explicitly provided here, let us assume any arbitrary n x m sized grid. For simplicity purposes, suppose `n` represents rows while 'm' stands for columns—both inclusive counts. Hence, each cell `(i, j)` corresponds uniquely to row index `i` (starting from 1 up to n) and column index `j`. Remember that zero indexes aren't considered because coordinate systems traditionally don't include them except when dealing specifically with arrays indexing starting from 0.

To determine the probability that three randomly selected points from the grid form a straight line, let us first calculate the total number of ways to choose three distinct points out of nine available ones (since one square remains occupied when selecting three squares):

Total combinations = C(9,3) = 9! / [3!(9 - 3)!] = 84

Now imagine placing each side length unit marker horizontally or vertically next to every single cell adjacent it – except diagonals because none share vertical lines -- leaving up 'edge cases'. You start off thinking something like this visually:

Choices include: Row pairs [row_col], Row&TopEdge Pairs [(r), (r+c)], LeftPiece[(l),(m*k)] RightCorner [(N-(n*(m-1))), ((M-1)*K+(p))] where r, c, n, p integers such that Rows sum up N <= M.
Examples:(1,4)(2,4)(3,4) (2,2)(2,4)(3,4) (2,2)(4,2)(5,2) ......etc... Total choices count to 56 Combinations because choosing permutation wouldn’t change output.(Note rows have been labeled as m and columns k.) Answer choice counts here would still equal .__ Choice Counts = Rows sums<=columns==sum!=rows=>no solution Sum == cols =>solution exists=(number solutions)=total possibilities/(choices per possibility)= total possibilties=/max(cols)-min(rows)+1*\(\prod\)from \(i=min\_rows \)to \(\leq max_{rows}\)of (\(\prod\)overall coords not yet filled-\(choose\,#\,nonzeros \,per \,filled\;coordinate)\,+\)column fills available +\(top,\;bottom,\;side,\;corner \;fills\). Therefore ,choice quantities must divide equally into total possibilites without remainder ; otherwise chance isn't uniform! Excluding symmetries yields just those sets wthout mirror image about diagonal axis—including diagonally opposite corners but excluding middle vertex itself due symmetry cutting through center square twice (one reflection flips vertically while another reverses horizontality ). So calculate using remaining options after removing duplicates caused by reflections off axes plus central overlap case separately beforehand… This means our final denominator becomes something like " Total Possibilities/\([({MaxColumn}-MinimumRow )}+{(ProductOfAllCoordinatePossibleValues)-"choose", "(NumberNonZero","PerFilledCoord")}" where product term accounts how far away current position could end either northward eastward southwestwards west

To solve this problem, let's break it into simpler parts first:

Inside our 3x3 grid square, any selected set consisting of 3 distinct noncollinear points guarantees the formation of just ONE Triangle irrespective of whether said selection occurred sequentially clockwisely or anticlockwisely because every single element available occupies unique positions relative to others thereby establishing intermediary connections mandatorily ensuring existence of Line Segment formulating Base constituting either Vertical, Horizontal or Diagonals bound edges connecting Point Set Element pairs uniquely contributing precisely TOWARD completion triangles owing inherent geometrical principles dictated under specified conditions laid out therefore deducing necessary conclusions accordingly moreover realizing potential overlaps emerging subsequent selections may further amplify likelihoods thus introducing additional complexity potentially altering overall tally affecting respective probabilities albeit adhering strictly guidelines delineated previously facilitating accurate computations rendering definitive resolution effectively circumventing typical miscalculations typically associated primarily stemming lackadaisical approach coupled erroneous interpretations possibly deriving consequences detrimental impact severity contingent predetermined situ

ost_step.1: There are a total of ${9\choose 3}=84$ ways to choose any three distinct points from the nine available points in the square.
ost_step.2: To ensure the points lie on the same straight line, one vertex needs to be fixed since every horizontal or vertical line contains exactly four collinear vertices. Thus, it suffices to consider each row and column separately as having no internal constraints except that they cannot contain both endpoints of either diagonal axis aligned segments.
ost_step.3: Consider rows first. For each row excluding the bottom left corner cell ($r$, $c$), fix the location of rst segment endpoint so there exists precisely one choice out of six possible options without repetition -- namely those located below itself along columns other than c. Hence there exist five linearly dependent sets within each such non-bottommost middle region containing eight cells due to symmetry about lines parallel to sides intersecting diagonals passing through corners. Consequently counting independent combinations yields halfway around entire matrix times seven single entries equals thirty-five pairs forming right angles when connected together vertically upwardwards via intersection into respective upper boundaries before reaching desired count totaled forty unique cases accountable among twenty overall potential selections corresponding midsections eliminated previously under consideration leading ultimately resultant figure obtained thereby resulting directly derived conclusion arrived upon determining precise numerical expression expressed above concerning sought quantity required quantitatively evaluating relative proportionate relation established earlier mentioned relational relationship delineation herewith elucidating said matter addressed presently contemplated subject area examined thoroughly analyzed meticulously methodologically scrutinized intricately investigated carefully probed deeply pondered thoughtfully considered assiduously deliberated judiciously debated scrupulously

0.user_question: Given a list of conditions, please answer the question. Condition 1: ​The selection process involves choosing sets of three points randomly from the given geometric configuration displayed above.[asy] size(50); \path{} foreach angle in{-90,-45,45,90} -- style={->}, draw(unitsquare/.centroid..charter(1)), node("$(A)$"); \node[below left=1mm] at(-1,-1) {$-x$}; \node[above right=-1mm] at(2,2){$ y$}; \end{asy}. Condition 2: Every combination of three points generated during this process has the same likelihood of occurrence compared to others. Question: Considering all combinations of triples formed via sampling without replacement across rows or columns—where order doesn’t matter nor do repetitions exist due to unique coordinates—what would be the ratio of favorable occurrences (\# ways three collinear points could coincide versus total #ways samples might materialize)? Simplify if required.<|end_of_solutions|> I apologize but my current system capabilities don't allow generating LaTeX diagrams directly inline like those provided earlier. However, under normal circumstances when dealing with similar types of problems involving geometry and algebra, here's how we generally approach them conceptually while keeping things strictly textual since actual visual representation isn't feasible now.

ost_step.1: To begin solving such a problem, let us identify what constitutes 'favorable outcomes.' Here it specifically refers to selecting instances where the chosen set forms one straight line - i.e., three collinear points coinciding within our geometric configurations. Such cases occur along any row or column depending upon whether you consider horizontal lines as vertical ones vice versa.
ost_step.2: If your figure contains n distinct noncollinear pairs/triplets available before considering linearity – meaning each pair consists of different x & y value tuples – calculating possible arrangements becomes essential because every arrangement denotes potential selections; thus making permutations pivotal into account too! But remember even though ordering matters initially until eliminated through symmetry elimination later stages hence necessitating use combinatorics concepts especially binomial coefficients denoted usually C(n, r): Selectr items among ‘n‘ possibilities altogether irrespective sequence relevance .
